captions.text:
Too long have you sat
in the shadows.

I would stay still
if I were you.

I will draw you, saruman,
as poison is drawn from a wound.

Saruman's voice:
If I go, theoden dies.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (4/9) Movie CLIP - Healing the King (2002) HD

comments.text:

ready to take the most important journey in life, Google *Truth Contest* 
and check out the top entry. The truth will set you free.﻿

comments.text:
I believe that it's wrong to judge a person based solely on their physical 
appearance but only someone who was blind, deaf, and locked in a box 
couldn't tell that Wormtongue was a bad guy the second he walked on screen! 
In fact all the characters in this franchise seem to be totally oblivious 
to the examples of pure evil standing right in front of them! Like with 
Gandalf and Sauramon; him being traitor would have been a shock if he 
didn't live in a tower so ominous it might as well have had a neon sign on 
top of it saying:  I'M THE VILLIAN! I'M THE VILIAN!.﻿

comments.text:
Tolkien taught kids that kings were superior to democracy. In democracy, 
many people representing opposing sides must compromise to find acceptable 
policy for all. This eliminates the fast government fixes, the 
interested-corruption that economically destroys a population before it 
functionally destroys its government.

comments.author: Major Moe

comments.text:
How ironic then that Tolkien was a deeply devout Christian.
"The Lord of the Rings is of course a fundamentally religious and Catholic 
work; unconsciously so at first, but consciously in the revision. That is 
why I have not put in, or have cut out, practically all references to 
anything like 'religion', to cults or practices, in the imaginary world. 
For the religious element is absorbed into the story and the symbolism." - 
JRR Tolkien

Tolkien used religious thinking a lot when he wrote this. It was the 
foundation for his stories. The beginning of the Silmarillion sounds almost 
identical to the book of Genesis.
comments.author: Salaisor

comments.text:
Shut the hell up about religion, it's just a movie about old times, don't 
add bullshit to it. Lord of the Rings is itself with no religions, just the 
story itself.
comments.author: PowerDragon999

comments.text:
+James Cowan Well, expelling religious thinking would probably expel out 
Tolkien's whole Ainulindalë account from the Silmarillion then. You might 
as well expel Tolkien for being so idiotic to be Catholic and infusing much 
of his religious worldview into Middle-earth's cosmology. You might as well 
expel out Tolkien's reasons for the fall of Numenor in the Akallabeth, the 
story of how the Numenoreans were deceived by Sauron and worshipped Morgoth 
in defiance of the Valar.
comments.author: mechadoggy

comments.text:
Tolkien greatly disliked the idea of wizards not using a staff or so for 
their magic. He felt the "fairy tale" genre had dumben down the greatness 
of mythology and in his attemt to restore it, he created the foundation of 
modern epic fantasy. many haters rage about it and tries to deny it, but 
Tolkien, along with a few other authors of that time, is the main source of 
all modern fantasy that came afterwards.
